title: Elementary Concepts in Risk Management
description: This is an elementary course that introduces current issues and special topics in risk management. Students are required to present and discuss books and current articles in the related topics assigned by the instructor. Advisory: For majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) learn basic concepts in risk management; (2) improve their presentation and communication skills; and (3) improve their spoken and written English.
syllabus: This is an elementary course that introduces current issues and special topics in RMSC.Students are required to present and discuss books and current articles in the related topics.

title: Introduction to Risk Management
description: This course aims at providing a focused introduction to various concepts of risk and risk measures from a scientific perspective. The course will discuss the various roles that risk plays in insurance and financial applications. Current risk measures such as value at risk and shortfall risk will be introduced. These measures will be calculated for recent financial losses to illustrate their usefulness in risk management.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) understand the meaning and basic characteristics of risk and insurance; (2) appreciate the major methods of handling risk, including risk control techniques and risk financing techniques; (3) understand the law of large numbers and its application to insurance; (4) explain the legal principle of insurance; (5) acquire basic knowledge of financial and insurance products; and (6) understand the basic components of financial risk management, namely market risk, credit risk and operational risk management.

title: Simulation Methods for Risk Management Science and Finance
requirements: Prerequisite:RMSC2001 or consent of instructor
description: This course starts with presenting standard topics in simulation including random variable generations, variance reduction methods and statistical analysis of simulation outputs. The course then reviews the applications of these methods to derivative security pricing. Topics addressed include: importance sampling, martingale control variables, stratification and the estimation of derivatives. Additional topics include the use of low discrepancy sequence (quasi-random numbers), pricing American options and scenario simulation for risk management.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) understand the basic financial derivatives and their pricing;  (2) learn the simulation of stochastic processes, in particular Ito’s processes;  (3) learn the application of Ito’s lemma in simulation;  (4) understand value at risk for measuring market risk;  (5) acquire programming skills in EXCEL VBA; and  (6) use variance reduction to enhance simulation quality.

title: Financial Data Analytics with Machine Learning
requirements: Prerequisite:RMSC2001, STAT2001 and STAT2006, or consent of instructor
description: This course covers modern data analysis techniques that are commonly used in finance and risk management. Topics include applications of multivariate techniques for data cleansing and modeling such as principal component analysis and canonical correlation analysis to asset management, Extreme Value theory, Value-at-Risks, GARCH modeling in estimating volatility, time series methods in term-structure analysis. Besides, the next few introductory topics in machine learning will also be covered, such as recommender system, logistic regression, k-means clustering, perceptrons, decision trees, artificial neural network, stochastic gradient descent, Naive Bayes Classifiers and Bayesian networks.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) understand the basic notion of copulas and perform simulations according to the Black-Scholes model that facilitates for financial data cleansing;(2) grasp the idea of using GARCH to model the evolutions of volatilities and correlations;(3) calibrate various risk measures with the use of Extreme Value Theory; (4) use principal component analysis and canonical correlation analysis and understand its connection with simple recommender systems and its applications in term-structures of interest rates;(5) carry out cluster analysis with various machine learning tools such as perceptrons, classification trees, k-means clustering algorithm, Bayes classifiers;(6) grasp the concept of ANN and logit regression for categorical data analysis;(7) analyse real data using suitable proper techniques from both statistics and machine learning and write reports to summarise findings;(8) understand how to consider problems from different perspectives, particularly related to those in finance and risk management science, and analyse quantitative evidence in a critical manner.
syllabus: Business, Finance and Risk Management Science. Statistical packages such as R, SASand EXCEL will be used to demonstrate these methods. Topics are as follows:• Simulating Multivariate Normal Random Numbers • Estimating Volatilities and Correlations • Risk Measure and Extreme Value Theory• Principal Component Analysis, Recommender Systems• Binary Logistic Regression, Multinomial Logit, Perceptrons• Decision Tree • k-means Clustering • Artificial Neural Network, Stochastic Gradient Descent
recommended_readings: 1. Hull, J., Risk Management and Financial Institutions, Prentice Hall2. Johnson, R.A. and Wichern, D.W. Applied Multivariate statistical analysis, 6th edition, Prentice Hall3. David Ruppert and David S. Matteson, Statistics and Data Analysis for Financial Engineering: with R examples,  2nd ed. 2015 edition, Springer4. Kevin P. Murphy and Francis Bach, Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective (Adaptive Computation and Machine Learning), 1st edition, The MIT Press5. (日)中井悅司, 機器學習入門之道, 人民郵電

title: Statistical Modelling in Financial Markets
requirements: Prerequisite:RMSC2001 or consent of instructor
description: This course is designed to introduce the current developments in risk management in the financial markets. Risk management ideas associated with three general important areas in finance will be discussed: asset management, derivative pricing and fixed income models. Emphasis will be placed on the statistical modelling aspects on some of the commonly used models in these areas.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) explain the notion of variation as a measure of risk and its relationship to statistics and risk management;  (2) demonstrate the ability to understand the concepts of mean-variance analysis and Markowitz optimal portfolio for a one-period investment;  (3) interpret and infer from the mean-variance analysis and the ideas of efficient frontiers and minimum variance portfolio;  (4) understand the notion of factor models and their relationships to linear regressions;  (5) relate the celebrated CAPM model with factor models and their statistical underpinnings;  (6) explain the concepts of APT and its reconciliation with the CAPM;  (7) explain and demonstrate the basic notions of diffusions and their applications to finance and risk management;  (8) demonstrate a basic understanding of Ito’s calculus;  (9) demonstrate a working knowledge of applying Ito’s calculus, in particular with respect to standard Brownian motion;  (10) differentiate both conceptually and practically the notion of integration by parts between ordinary and Ito’s calculus;  (11) apply Ito’s calculus to option pricing and the Black-Scholes formula; and  (12) acquire the necessary background for other courses in risk management and finance, including but not limited to RMSC4001, RMSC4002, RMSC4005 and RMSC4007.
syllabus: This course is designed to introduce the current developments of risk management in the financial markets. Two general important areas of risk management in finance: (1) asset management and (2) derivative pricing. Emphasis will be placed on the statistical modeling aspects on some of the commonly used models in the area of market risk.
required_readings: David G. Luenberger, Investment Science, 7th edition, Oxford University Press
recommended_readings: David Ruppert, Statistics and Finance – An Introduction, Springer-Verlag

title: Theory of Risk and Insurance
description: This course covers the theory of risk and its applications to insurance. Topics include: classical and stochastic risk models, ruin theory, claims modelling and evaluations, risk premium pricing, loss distributions and creditability theory.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) understand, in an actuarial context, what is meant by the word “model”, how and why models are used, their advantages and their limitations;  (2) understand the important results that can be obtained from these models for the purpose of making business decisions and the approaches that can be used to determine these results;  (3) generalise knowledge from the actuarial sector to other business environments; and  (4) solve the questions in Exams M and C offered by the Society of Actuaries.
syllabus: Risk can be thought as the potential losses in accidents. The amount of loss in each accident and the frequency of the occurrence of accidents should be considered to quantify risk. To eliminate these potential losses, individual will seek for insurance. From an individual point of view, insurance is an economic device whereby the individual substitutes a small certain cost (the premium) for a large uncertain financial loss (the contingency insured against) that would exist if there were not for insurance. In this course, the modeling of frequency and severity will be studied. The aggregate loss model will then be introduced. Then credibility theory will be discussed.
required_readings: Klugman, S.A., Panjer, H.H. and Willmot, G.E. Loss Models: From Data to Decisions. 2nd Edition. John Wiley, 2004.

title: Stochastic Calculus for Finance and Risk
requirements: Prerequisite:RMSC2001 & STAT3007 or consent of instructor
description: This course starts with the introduction of the concepts of arbitrage and risk-neutral pricing. It then proceeds to discuss the stochastic calculus foundations for continuous-time finance models. Topics include: Brownian motion, stochastic integral, Itô's formula, Girsanov's change of measure, and the relationship between stochastic calculus and partial differential equations. Examples will be taken from equity options, including the Black-Scholes formula for foreign exchange and term-structure models.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) do the basic option pricing (the Black-Sholes approach) for European and American options under the assumption that the stock price behaves as a drifted Brownian Motion; and  (2) do the basic manipulation of stochastic integrations and stochastic partial differential equations.
syllabus: Stochastic Calculus is an advance tool for modeling prices of risky assets. In this course you will learn the basics of stochastic calculus without going through the rigorous mathematics of measure theory. The following topics will be covered in this course:  1. Examples of arbitrage and pricing in a single period forward option 2. The multi-period binary model 3. Conditional expectation and Martingale  4. Continuous stochastic process and Brownian motion 5. Stochastic integral and Ito’s formula 6. Stochastic differential equation 7. Applications of stochastic calculus in finance 8. The Black-Scholes Model and pricing for European option
recommended_readings: A course in Financial Calculus / A. Etherridge Introduction to Stochastic Calculus with Application / F. C. Klebaner

title: Operational Risk Management
requirements: Pre-requisite: RMSC2001 or consent of instructor.
description: This course introduces the general methodology for operational risk management. Special emphasis will be placed on the analytical and modeling techniques for operational risk. Contents include Basel regulations, loss models, extreme value theory, copula, operational value-at-risk and operational risk derivatives. Machine learning techniques for managing operational risk will also be explored. The use of statistical packages R will be demonstrated.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to1. understand the Basel regulations on operational risk. 2. build statistical models for operational risk3. understand extreme value theory and copula models4. calculate operational value-at-risk and price operational risk derivatives5. use statistical software to conduct machine learning algorithms and statistical inference and for operation risk models
syllabus: Operational risk refers to the uncertainties and hazards a company faces under its day-to-day business activities. It usually involves some events that rarely happen but lead to huge lost. Therefore, extreme value theory is crucial to characterize the behaviors of these events. Moreover, copula is an important tool to model the dependency among the operational risks from several business lines. In this course we investigate the use of extreme value theory and copula on managing operational risk. Machine learning techniques for managing operational risk will also be explored.
recommended_readings: Cruz, M. 2002.  Modeling, Measuring and Hedging Operational Risk. John Wiley & Sons, London.Panjer, H.H.  2006. Operational Risk – Modeling Analytics. John Wiley & Sons, New Jersey.

title: Risk Management with Derivatives Concepts
requirements: Prerequisite: RMSC2001, 4001 & 4003 or consent of instructor.
description: This course aims at understanding the application of derivatives theories for the practical risk management. It starts by reviewing basic concepts of pricing and hedging derivatives, like risk-neutral valuation, arbitrage strategies, hedging strategies, implied volatilities and the Greeks. The Value-at-Risk framework for derivatives positions is discussed. Student will also learn how to apply option theoretic approach to credit risk management. Specifically, the capital structure model will be applied to measure the default probability. The Moody's KMV methodology and CreditRisk+ are introduced. Advisory: For Risk Management Science, Quantitative Finance and Risk Management Science, Statistics majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) understand derivative pricing theories;  (2) understand structure products and their risk management;  (3) conduct risk management reports of financial products;  (4) enhance their teamwork and presentation skills; and  (5) understand structural credit risk models.

title: Advanced Statistical Theory in Risk Management
requirements: For students in MSc Risk Management Science
description: This course discusses modern applications of advanced statistical methods in finance. Methods include Monte Carlo simulation, EWMA and GARCH model for estimating volatilities and correlations, calculation of Value at Risk using different approaches, data mining methods including Principal component analysis, Logistic regression, Multinomial logit, Linear Discriminant analysis, Classification Tree and Artificial Neural Network.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) analyse real data using R, EXCEL and SAS; (2) simulate multivariate normal random vectors; (3) build a GARCH and EWMA model for volatilities and correlations of stock prices; (4) compute VaR using historical simulation, normal model, t model and extreme value model; (5) understand the Basel Accord; (6) perform Principal component analysis and its application to compute VaR; (7) perform classification using Binary logistic regression, Linear discrimination analysis, Classification tree, Artificial neural network and k-means clustering.

title: Principles of Risk Management
requirements: For students in MSc Risk Management Science
description: This course provides students with fundamental concepts of risk and risk management. It further introduces risk management tools used in financial products. Topics include market risk, operational risk and integrated risk management.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) identify various kinds of financial risks and tools to manage the risks; (2) apply basic mathematical, financial and statistical techniques in risk management science; (3) understand basic management techniques of market risk and credit risk.

title: Risk Measures
requirements: For students in MSc Risk Management Science; For students in MPhil Risk Management Science
description: Risk measurement and quantification are the fundamentals of risk management procedures. This course discusses various types of risk measures but mainly focuses on the methodologies of calculating Value-at-Risk (VaR) such as historical simulation, parametric VaR, delta-gamma approximation and Monte-Carlo simulation. The uses of VaR in risk management are also addressed. Topics include portfolio risk management, asset allocation and measuring the performance of portfolio managers.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) understand the rigorous definition of risk measures in terms of probability theory;  (2) numerical calculation of value-at-risk (VaR) and expected shortfall for linear portfolios;  (3) VaR and shortfall for nonlinear portfolios with derivatives positions;  (4) backtesting VaR; (5) stress testing;  (6) VaR applications in the banking industry and its use in margin calculations;  (7) practical team work on VaR applications.

requirements: For students in MSc Risk Management Science; For students in MPhil Risk Management Science

outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) calculate individual risk metrics on single investments, such as VaR, CVaR & historical drawdowns and including certain well know risk ratios; (2) perform Portfolio Analytics, such as Mean-Variance & Mean-CVaR Portfolio Optimisation, calculating the Capital Market Line & Tangency Portfolio, estimating the co-variance & correlation matrices;  (3) tell the business; financial & political issues arising from the 2006-2010 Global Economic and Financial Crisis; the fall of the global financial system and its implications inclusive of case studies on Exposure Management Advisory; Derivatives - Risk and Returns;  (4) know about Global Core-Satellite Active Advisory Portfolio Construction and Asset Allocation theories and implementation inclusive of past 7 year class portfolio projects performance review and takeaways;  (5) understand and analyse FINMA/MAS/HKMA/SFC Approved Structured Note Series inclusive of principal protected/yield enhanced/participation/leveraged FX/Fixed Income/Equity/Commodity/Energy and ETF Indices formation; (6) understand in principle Emerging Private Wealth Management (PWM) Business Model and Risk Management Framework inclusive of HKMA/SFC endorsed Type 4 Portfolio based Managed Advisory / PWM Selling and Suitability Process;  (7) competitively analyse and compare re-owned Global Master's of Science program in financial engineering/risk management science and explore Asset/Risk Management Career Interests and Possibilities; (8) identify different risk associated with various financial product; (9) understand the decision making process of asset managers/ traders; (10) understand the latest implementation of Basel III Liquidity Standard in HK.

title: Interest Rates and Fixed Incomes Risk Management
requirements: For students in MSc Risk Management Science; For students in MSc Data Sci & Business Stat
description: Fixed income securities are highly sensitive to the fluctuation of interest rates. Thus interest rate modelling becomes crucial for pricing and managing fixed income securities. This course introduces various types of fixed income securities and interest rate models. It covers the celebrated Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) model as well as some term-structure models including Ho-Lee, Hull-White and the CIR models.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) derive the mathematical formula for basic instruments of the fixed income markets; (2) identify the interest rate risks of a fixed income portfolio, and to use benchmark securities to hedge the duration risk of a fixed income portfolio; (3) calibrate the interest rate curves using different types of interest rates models, and to hedge the interest rate risk of a fixed income portfolio based on those models; (4) apply stochastic calculus to price some vanilla fixed income instruments;  (5) price exotic fixed income instruments using Libor market models; (6) use MS Excel to perform the above fitting and pricing.

title: Credit Risk Management
requirements: For students in MSc Risk Management Science
description: The Credit Crisis of 2007 devastated the global financial industry and demonstrated that, despite unprecedented financial sophistication, proper credit risk management is vital for the good health of any financial institution. In this course, we will cover the cat-and-mouse history of regulation of credit, taking us to the present day. Along the way, we cover various attempts at modeling and quantifying credit risk, which will lead us through topics like VaR, copulas, credit derivatives, different credit risk methodologies (e.g. Credit Risk Plus, CreditMetrics) and much else besides. We will also discuss various case histories of financial institutions failing due to poor credit risk management.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to (1) describe how to calculate credit risk measures via various methodologies; (2) explain how to mitigate credit risk; (3) value and utilise credit risk derivatives; (4) discuss the evolution and present day implications of regulation, as pertains to credit risk management; (5) recall and expound on various cases of credit risk mis-management.

description: Students are required to conduct research under the supervision of their advisors.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should be able to (1) understand related background and knowledge about the research field that the student works on; (2) conduct research projects under the guidance and supervision of his/her supervisor(s).
syllabus: This course requires students to meet their supervisors regularly to discuss research problems, and/or other relevant topics that can contribute to the students theses.
